title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds a lack of reliable statistical information on franchise businesses despite their growing importance in the American marketplace. Existing data on franchise failures is scarce, leading to the dissemination of inaccurate and misleading information in promotional materials. The Act aims to provide accurate statistical information on franchising to the public, prevent misleading data from Federal Government agencies, and ensure prospective investors have the necessary information to make informed decisions about investing in franchise businesses. The Act aims to provide accurate statistical information on franchising to the public, prevent misleading data from Federal Government agencies, and ensure prospective investors have the necessary information to make informed decisions about investing in franchise businesses. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. The Act requires all entities selling franchises to file a copy of the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department. The document must be the most recent version and the most restrictive in terms of requirements and limitations imposed on franchisees. The franchise disclosure document must be filed annually with the Commerce Department, and copies can be requested by Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and other Federal agencies. It is illegal for franchisors to make false statements in connection with any advertisement or disclosure document to prospective franchisees. The franchise broker is prohibited from implying that the Commerce Department or any other Federal agency has reviewed or approved the franchise disclosure document. The Commerce Department is required to establish procedures for collecting and publishing statistical information on franchise ownership and practices within 240 days of the enactment of this section. The Commerce Department is mandated to publish statistical information on franchise ownership and practices, using disclosure documents as the main source. This includes compiling data on franchisors, types of franchise businesses, growth rates, turnover, and failures. Collaboration with various organizations is required to identify additional categories for analysis. The Commerce Department collaborates with Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and other organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data analysis. This includes periodic questionnaires of franchisors or franchisees to supplement information from disclosure documents. Periodic questionnaires are used to supplement information from disclosure documents. The Commerce Department is required to publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices annually. The Commerce Department must annually publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, which will be shared with Congress and the public. CENSUS DATA ON FRANCHISE BUSINESSES. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and Congress to establish criteria and procedures. A report on cost-effective data collection methods and data categories for franchise businesses will be submitted to Congress within 280 days. The Bureau of the Census will consult with the Federal Trade Commission and Congress to determine cost-effective data collection methods and data categories for franchise businesses to be included in the Business Census. A report will be submitted to Congress within 280 days. SEC. 5. RULES, REGULATIONS AND FEES. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to make rules and regulations to implement the Act, including fees for filing requirements. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, including "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise," outlining the requirements and relationships involved in the sale of franchises. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, including the rights granted by a franchisor to a franchisee to engage in selling goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark or conforming to quality standards set by the franchisor. Franchises must operate under the franchisor's trademark and receive knowledge, assistance, and controls from the franchisor in their business operations. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while the term "franchisor" refers to a person who grants a franchise. The franchisee must adhere to the franchisor's trademark and quality standards, receive support and guidance, and may be required to make payments to the franchisor or its affiliates. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for subfranchises and commercial relationships based on representations of meeting specific criteria. The term "franchisee" is defined as a person granted a franchise, and "franchisor" as the one who grants it. A "subfranchise" involves a contract where a person pays a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
